Posts.Content: Hi sasha I think its good to get a second opinion and your oncologist sounds like he should give up medicine and try a profession where bedside manner doesnt matter.... Anyway what i was going to say was the side effects you get from the treatments vary however the main thingtha happens to everybody is hair loss... This starts around two weeks after your first dose of chemo and its the E epirubicin which causes this... It is red and given through a cannula or longerterm device such as a picc or hickman line. The F is 5 Flourouricil which tbh doesnt really do much and the C is cyclophosphamide which can cause bladder irritation so think you might need to be a bit wary of it... The E also makes you pee pink for a day... If your drink lots of water before and after the chemo it helps flush it through your body. Paclitaxel is also sometimes called taxol... And it is given weekly this means its not so much all at one go so your kidney should hopefully be ok with it.... FEC tends to cause nausea and vomitting more than taxol, but not everybody gets sick.... Other common side effects can be feeling tired, sore mouth, ulcers, funny taste, constipation, diarrhoea, indigestion, garstric reflux, gritty eyes, watering eyes, and risk of infections due to low blood count. I think its probably wise to have chemo so long as its not going to cause serious damage to your kidney.... So yb you can ask to be referred to a renal consultant to discuss it with him too... But if the kidney problem is not life threatening then i think having the chemo is def worth considering as the cancer is life threatening if left untreated. you will get a bigger benefit from chemo the worse the prognosis is.... But as its lobularou houkd get quite. Good effects from hormone therapy too which starts after chemo has finished.... Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Proposed chemo regime - looking for advice, info, help please

Posts.Content: Hi sasha I think its good to get a second opinion and your oncologist sounds like he should give up medicine and try a profession where bedside manner doesnt matter.... Anyway what i was going to say was the side effects you get from the treatments vary however the main thingtha happens to everybody is hair loss... This starts around two weeks after your first dose of chemo and its the E epirubicin which causes this... It is red and given through a cannula or longerterm device such as a picc or hickman line. The F is 5 Flourouricil which tbh doesnt really do much and the C is cyclophosphamide which can cause bladder irritation so think you might need to be a bit wary of it... The E also makes you pee pink for a day... If your drink lots of water before and after the chemo it helps flush it through your body. Paclitaxel is also sometimes called taxol... And it is given weekly this means its not so much all at one go so your kidney should hopefully be ok with it.... FEC tends to cause nausea and vomitting more than taxol, but not everybody gets sick.... Other common side effects can be feeling tired, sore mouth, ulcers, funny taste, constipation, diarrhoea, indigestion, garstric reflux, gritty eyes, watering eyes, and risk of infections due to low blood count. I think its probably wise to have chemo so long as its not going to cause serious damage to your kidney.... So yb you can ask to be referred to a renal consultant to discuss it with him too... But if the kidney problem is not life threatening then i think having the chemo is def worth considering as the cancer is life threatening if left untreated. you will get a bigger benefit from chemo the worse the prognosis is.... But as its lobularou houkd get quite. Good effects from hormone therapy too which starts after chemo has finished.... Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Proposed chemo regime - looking for advice, info, help please

Posts.Content: Calcium can be benign or malignant but if they arent sure I think you would be better having a stereotactic biopsy to confirm whether it's cancerous or not.... Some malignant calcs have a specific look and your may not be showing that hence the reason they are willing to recheck you in six months..... Many people feel that we over treat DCIS and maybe your doc is of this opinion.... However if it was me I think I'd want to know one way or the other now and not be worrying for six months.... However if the calcs are DCIS this is pre invasive and can't spread anywhere else and it's pretty slow growing normally..... I would say if he's calling you back in six months he's not overly concerned... But at the same time I really do think they should be able to give you an answer now. Here is a couple of guidance pages about breast assessment clinics. http://www.cancerscreening.nhs.uk/breastscreen/bsu.html http://www.macmillan.org.uk/Cancerinformation/Testsscreening/Breastscreening/Assessmentclinics.aspx
Posts.Title: findings

Posts.Content: Its not uncommon on chemo annabel. Its probably attacking the cancer cells.... Some people even get a chemo flare which can be redness and swelling around the site of the cancer. If your worried call your bcn though xxx
Posts.Title: sore breast lump and armpit

Posts.Content: Side effects happen to some patients taking drugs not to all patients..... They have to warn you of the "possible" side effects so you are fully informed before you start your treatment..... Some people will get every side effect gong and others will get none but most people will be somewhere in the middle and get some. No SEs doesnt mean it's not working just like getting every SE doesn't mean it's working too much, it just means your lucky. If your concerned do speak to your Bcn though. Lulu
Posts.Title: ANASTROZOLE - NO SIDE EFFECTS

Posts.Content: Lou can he not refer you to a vascular Or cardiology specialist as hes an oncologist and this isnt his specialty... Maybe go and see your gp and explain what is happening.... Also if you don't have faith in your onc you can ask for a second opinion or change who you see. Interesting article. As for the blood test can you not get your nurse or gp to do it at your surgery and get the results sent to the onc. Take care
Posts.Title: Am Losing My Mind!

Posts.Content: Hi Patricia.... Until you have been seen by the genetics team you won't know for sure if You fit the criteria for testing..... Not everybody referred will be suitable for testing..... Only 20% of those tested will be positive for a gene.... If your cancer is triple negative and you are under 40 or you have strong family history they can sometimes do a fast track gene test if you are contemplating bilateral mastectomy. Otherwise it's routine.... The fast track can be one itching two weeks, but mostly it takes about 4 months for the full gene analysis.... This is where no gene change is known in your family..... The predictive test they can do if somebody else is known to have a gene test and only takes about a month..... You will be fully counselled normally before they will test you... First they will want check your family history and get confirmation of the types and age of onset of the cancers.... Then you will get an explanation of you what the results could mean.... You dont have to be tested if you dont want to even if you fit the criteria not everybody wants to know. I have a brca2 gene mutation which was identified after I had a second breast cancer at 40 after the original one at 37 and have just completed chemo for a recurrence at 43... I work in breast cancer genetics so if you need any help let me know.
Posts.Title: genetic testing

Posts.Content: I have also had eye problems since having chemo in 2009.... I had epi-cmf and it was the cmf that started it and have had to use eye drops ever since..... Was at optician today and still dry. i use hypromellose eye drops and ave used carbomer in the past and she recommended i get sime if them again too... Also said eating anti oxidants like berries are good for eyes and brazil nuts which are high in selenium help dryness.... Don think they have much thy can do to stop the watering.... She also said that eyes start deteriorating from 40 so in my case its likely to be a combination of both age and chemo. also suffer from the scabby nose and post-nasal drip since docetaxel and carboplatin which. Finished 6 months ago but nose has never been quite right since chemo in 2009..... Also have naseptin, which is good, abd also use vaseline and nasonex nasal spray. Which has helped the choking which i got from the Post nasal drip. also have dry mouth since starting tamoxifen in 2006 and use biotene oral balance saliva replacement gel, mouth still not quite right as it was destroyed by the docetaxel, but the gel tastes nice and does help. hope you all can get something to help
Posts.Title: Watery Eyes :(

Posts.Content: I have been on tamoxifen in and off since 2006 and for the first few months I had regular periods and then started to get really heavy prolonged bleeding and flooding.... Not everybody's periods stop on tamoxifen and for some people it can cause bleeding problems.... I had to get a gynae consult and have a biopsy and D and C.... All was ok but as there is a link with endometrial cancer they like to check these things out.... The link is for older women who have been on tamoxifen for longer than 5 years but the prefer to err on the side of caution with these things normally. I also to a mirena coil fitted when they were doing the D and C and this pretty much stopped my periods completely after the intitial few weeks of spotting... But it was great and only had it removed when I had a hysterectomy 18 months ago.
Posts.Title: tamoxifen and periods

Posts.Content: I bought some lovely scarves in asda for a fiver when I had chemo 3 years ago I had hung on to my favourites so just dug them out but I see asda have quite a few nice ones when I was there last time.
Posts.Title: Scarves headwear day n night

Posts.Content: Hi zoe I didnt tell my mum because i didnt want to worry it then came as a complete shock out the blue when i had to tell her i had breat cancer just a year after she had treatment for it. I did the dame when i got another tumour three years later because that time i thought it woukd be benign since then i always tell her if im being recalled or having a scan so that its not so distressing for her. It is really hard finding the right words. The first two times i had to just say i have cancer but the third time i was able to say they werent happy with my scan and i need to get a biopsy so that when i had to tell her the cancer had come back she didnt go hysterical this time..... Mums are great and its good to have her support and shoulder to cry on and for her to have yours to cry on too. Take care and hope it all goes well. Xxxx
Posts.Title: Worried about appointment

Posts.Content: Hi tinkers I think what flower meant was she was not offered an immediate recon as radiotherapy can affect it... Many units do not do immediate recons if there is a chance you may need radiotherapy.... Also frequently if you need chemo they will only offer delayed recon too as they want you to heal quickly and there is often a longer recover and a higher chance of problems following recon than following mastectomy..... But there are new advances being made all the time and different surgeons have their own preferences too. Lxx
Posts.Title: Waiting.....

Posts.Content: Hi Carole It's such a worry at the start of the journey.... But it does get easier as you go along. I have just finished 6 cycles of chemo and undergoing radiotherapy at the mo... Only have 5 to go..... I had surgery to remove the area of the regional recurrence and an ANC in sept before I started chemo. Hope you get on ok
Posts.Title: New to this

Posts.Content: Hi Carole I notice your kids are the same age as mine. I was diagnosed with bilateral breast cancer in 2006 and 2009 and had a recurrence of 2009 tumour last year in lymph nodes. Bilateral cancer is pretty rare but I was found to be carrying a brca 2 gene mutation. I remember back to those early days when I was first diagnosed and all you know is that you have cancer but you have no idea how bad it is... My mind was working over time and just thought the worst. Strangely not knowing I had cancer was worse than knowing I did..... Once you know what your dealing with then you can make plans. Hopefully you will get your results and treatment plan soon so you know what's happening. Take care
Posts.Title: New to this

Posts.Content: I had 5 weeks of rads in 2006 following a lumpectomy, I had another 5 weeks of rads to the other breast in 2009 following chemo and lumpectomy and now Im currently half way 4 weeks of rads to the upper chest folowing surgery and chemo for a recurrence. There is no comparison to my mind rads are a walk in the park compared to chemo.... Yes they can be tiring and you can get burned skin but there are no bone and muscles aches, no painful mouth, no disappearing nails, no numb and painful fingers, no nausea, no hairloss, no constipation and diarrhoea, no indigestion, no dry gritty eyes, no shortness of breath or fainting or palpitations... My experiences of chemo was so much worse than my experience of rads..... Sore burn skin and knackered but that was it.
Posts.Title: starting radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi sunnychair At my unit margins are 1mm so long as there is 1mm they don't consider it too close... And if it was closer its likely they would give radiotherapy to minimise the risk of recurrence. Lxx
Posts.Title: Tumour 5.5mm from chest wall

Posts.Content: Hi betty normally if you have a mastectomy you dont need radiotherapy... Especially if you have dcis only and no invasive component... Its possible thereis a small focus of infiltration seen on your mastectomy pathology.... Snb are not routinely carried out on women with dcis so it coud be that your team thought it was very likely to contain invasive cancer as well. As for the rads themselves they can cause damage to implants like encapsulation and hardening and may mean your require further surgery at a later stage to resolve this.... But even with invasive cancer rads are not routine following matectomy so its perhaps that the area affected was very large or the the cancer was very close to the muscle or there were some invasive or preinvasive cancer cells in the margin.... If they are offering it then its usually means its recommended in your situation as they generally wouldnt put you through it if they didnt think it was important for you to have it.... Good luck.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy after implant reconstruction

Posts.Content: It's common to have periods on tamoxifen and they can come and go a bit.... Sometimes they can be very heavy and prolonged. It's is most likely to be a side effect of tamoxifen as it can cause endometrial thickening which makes bleeding heavier and bit cloth. However I haven't heard of a link of methotrexate with periods but I'll maybe look into it and see if I can find out anything for you Kate.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Methotrexate (for RA) - Still Having Period??

Posts.Content: Hi sam Calcium deposits can be totally benign but sometimes can show very early cancer called DCIS.... This kind of cancer cannot spread anywhere so if its DCIS its unlikely to be in her lungs. Calcium deposits can sometimes only be distinguished by a pathologist so requires a biopsy.... This doesnt mean it will def be cancer it could well be just benign calcs and that is what they are trying to find out. If it is a recurrence of the cancer then it can still be treated.... I know a recurrence is every breast cancer patients worst fear but a recurrence doesnt mean its spread it means she would prob need more surgery but often that would be all.... I have had two primary cancers and one recurrence and my second diagnosis was definitely the worst!!!! It was my worst nightmare coming true. Fingers crossed for your wife that its benign and she doesnt need any more surgery or treatment.
Posts.Title: Calcium deposits on Mammogram

Posts.Content: Hi helen sorry your experience has been poor so far but i woud also suggest calling your bn they are till there for you no matter how long since you were diagnosed thy also sometimes run movin forward courses which helps you to move on after the initial surgery and treatment... You can also request a referral to a plastic surgeon to discuss your wound and scarring. Glad you have your onc appt you can also discuss your concerns with him. Xxx
Posts.Title: A bad day at the office

Posts.Content: Glad your feeling better now you know what your dealing with and what yiur facing kittycat. With regards to the rads i had 5 weeks so 3/4 is normal... Its usually between 3-6 weeks from what i have seen..... I have 20 to breast plus 5 boosters to the skin over the tumour area (usually only done if you have a lumepctomy)..... Amybe they do15 plus 5 as boosters maybe thats why they said 3/4 weeks as might depend if you have a lumpectomy or not. hope you cope ok with the chemo... I had 6 cycles of tax just finished in feb and wasnt too bad... Didnt make me sick just really tired and weak which was fine. i have had a few bone scans over the time its not too claustraphobic as it only stays over your head for a short time and there is space at the sides so your not completely enclosed..... Just have to remeber to drink loads and loads in the 2 hours after our injection.... Me and my friend went to the pub! LOL! its all happening so fast for you now... The picc line isnt nice getting inserted but its great once you ahve it as no messing around trying to find veins...... We have to put up a massive fight here to get any lines put in..... Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: My results

Posts.Content: sasha they are a centre of excellence for all things cancer... including lobular but not specifically lobular.... they do a lot of research and lead the way in terms of treatments.... but £3K is steep.   i have been doing a bit of reading since we spoke and although i havent found anything which says one type of chemo is better than another, i have found research stating chemo before surgery is just as effective as hormone therapy so isnt now indicated in the neo-adjuvant setting (before surgery) but there is still a good place for it after surgery.   the research compared women with lobular to women with ductal both on the same regime FEC and the outcome was that FEC was just as effective in the lobular group as in the ductal group  when given after surgery.   one of the aim s of the study was to determine if chemo before surgery reduced the likelihood of needing a mastectomy how ever it was still more likely  that those having neoadjuvant chemo would need and mx instead of a wle.... but possibly because those tumours were much larger in the first place.   not sure that will really help much.... can you request a second opinion? if you dont feel happy with your proposed treatment see if you can be refrred to another doctor who may offer alternative options or may agree with your original doc.   take care Lxxx
Posts.Title: Chemo for invasive lobular cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine Iv been on tamox off and on for 4 of the last 5 1/2 years... Didn't have any heartburn for the first three years until I had Chemo and this started the problem nd after I finished Chemo and went back on tamox it didn't resolve.... I take omeprazole, which helps.... I'm back on Chemo and off tamox again but need a higher dose when on Chemo as it feels like a really hard stone pressing in my chest, and can't sleep lying down... Think I have about 6 pillows at the mo. I also have a sensitivity to ibuprofen which causes me to get a stomach ulcer so not sure if I'm just uber sensitive to gastric problems.... I haven't taken brufen for 4 years now and the stomach eating itself feeling doesn happen any more. Hope you get some relief from the ranitidine but if that doesn't help either do ask your gp for something like omeprazole or lasoprazole to see if that would be suitable for you. Take care Lulu
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and heartburn

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine you are obviously very worried however a red swollen breast is rarely a sign of recurrence.... Only really if you had a type of breast cancer called inflammatory BC which isnt very common in the first place...... Redness and swelling are much more likely to be infection although you can also get lymphoedema in your breast as well as your arm or hand..... A painful lump in your breast is less likely to be cancer than say something benign like a cyst or fibroadenoma.... Its wise to get it checked out and glad our GP has organised an urgent scan.... You didnt say what grade the tumour was but likely to be grade 1 or 2 if no chemo.... So extremely unlikely for a grade 1 or 2 tumour to grow to plum size in such a short space of time... In fact even a grade 3 tumour would normally take much longer to develop into a tumour the size of a plum which is about 4cm.... No scan is 100% so there is a slight chance it may be a cancer which has been there longer and not picked up on mammo or US but again this is unlikely, although not impossible. I would say from what you have said its much less likely to be a recurrence or even a new cancer and more likely to be something benign.... Fingers crossed the ABs work and help put your mind at rest a bit before your scan..... If it is a recurrence or new cancer we are all here for you and you will get through it too. I have had a new primary and a recurrence and still got a very good prognosis just means we have to have more treatment but you get there in the end sweetie.... And as my friend said recently stop consulting Dr Google... Hes no good! Take care.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer reocurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne Even if a lot of our hair comes out it may not all come out... The main hairloss happens around the two week mark and a lot of people think the cold cap isn't working but it's maybe worthwhile trying it again next cycle as its very likely you will lose some but not all and when it falls out t always looks more in your hand than it does on your head for some reason. If you decide the cold cap isn't for you then there are lots of options like wigs, scarves, hats, bandanas etc. Iv had chemo twice but never used the cold cap and the first time around my head was extremely painful from about day 14 and my hair started falling out the next day and shaved it all off on day 17. The second time again my head got quite sore but this time from day 10 and my hair started coming out on day 12. I didn't shave it this time just cut it very short and it looks like bumfluff (baby monkey hair or duck down). I wear a wig sometimes but often just go bare headed. The pain I felt wasn't like a burning sensation was more of stabbing forks into my head..... It lasted for a few days and some headaches but then subsided.... Try some pain killers to see if that helps. With respect of the cold cap stopping chemo from working this is not entirely true and has been researched many times... it can cause less chemo to get to the skull but bone mets in the skull are extremely rare, but it doesn't cause less chemo to get to the brain or anywhere else in the body. Take care Lulu x
Posts.Title: hair loss

Posts.Content: you will sometimes see it written down as LVI it is lymphovascular invasion and it means that within the blood or lymphatic vessels within the cancer there are some cancer cells. oncologists and surgeons dont think it affects the risk very much and it wont usually make a difference between having chemo or not although some cautious oncs might give chemo based on this but its usually given based on size, grade and lymph node involvement... and for a grade 3 tumour chemo is usually standard treatment. good luck
Posts.Title: What does it mean when it has progressed in to blood vessels?

Posts.Content: Has she had or is she having a mastectomy? You can get what's called occult tumours which you cannot see on mammogram they are quite rare. But you can also have tumours which kill themselves off but have obviously become invasive at some point to allow spread to the lymph nodes. Although Iv not had first hand experience I have heard of it. You might find more help in the breastcancer or cancer of unknown primary (cup) forums. Hope treatment goes well for your mum xxxxx
Posts.Title: My mum has recently been told she has breast cancer but doesnt have...

Posts.Content: Hi Flower in terms of it being invasive or not i would disagree with tinkers in that if it were non invasive it would be Tis stage0.... T1 stage1 is invasive but small and no obvious spread.   the prognosis for breast cancers like this is excellent...  an average of 90% of women with diagnosed with BC today will still be around in 10 years time.... it can be disconcerting to read things in terms of ten years but soon we will be talking about 15 or 20 years.... the figures we use are from those who were diagnosed over 10 years ago and some major advances have come into place in that time with new chemos, new hormonal treatments, widespread use of herceptin for her2+ tumours and improvements in surgical techniques, screening methods and analysism etc   your own specific prognosis can be worked out by your onc or using online calculators but from your current diagnosis and if you have 5 years of tamoxifen your chance of survival is nearly 95% by 10 years... so yes i would say thats pretty good!   take care Lulu xxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Flower its an awful lot to take in... yes they wont have the full picture till after your Mx and SNB.... but try not to jump too far ahead..... what you know is right now... is its small, not the highest grade, responsive to hormones, and not in your nodes.... lots of positives.... try to take it one step at a time. as your onc said  very few will have an actual change to the initial stage but its something to keep in the back of your mind.... its much more likely that a grade 2 at biopsy may be a grade 3 on pathology, or that it might be a few mm bigger than first thought. the bottom line is you have cancer in your body and you will be getting rid of it very soon. it might be a good idea to speak to your gp about your feelings maybe you need something stronger to help rather than the diazepam. Lulu xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Hi flower.... Meant to say I'm from scotland too...... From Edinburgh. Some units will perform scans routinely when diagnosed with an invasive tumour.... Sometimes when the tumour is bigger or multi focal or when it's the nodes they will do a liver CT, bone scans and chest X-ray.... I'm presuming because yours is multifocal they are doing the scans. As long as the cancer isn't in another organ it is still cureable but they cannot tell who and who isn't cured until you survive for 40 years and die from old age.... Even if it is in another organ it is still treatable too but they don't tend to use the cured word unless you have what's called a triple negative tumour which your isn't.... On average 90% of women will be alive in 10 year or longer... Most people are cured. Unfortunately until ou have all the answers you will still be worried but I do think that maybe you are suffering bit more than normal so you might benefit from counselling or maybe even antidepressants... Although they take about 2-3 weeks to start working.... Might be worth chatting to your gp. As for the baby situation.... You are only 37.... There's no reason why you cannot have another baby after this... And there is a new document issued by the royal college of obstetricians and gynaecologists last year supporting women conceiving after cancer.... As a midwife the biggest increase in childbearing is in women 40 and over.... Don't write your life off until you have all the facts. Take care Lulu xxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Flower thats great news..... Hopefully you are feeling more reassured by this. Lxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Jan do chase it up if you still feel something isn't right.... You know your breasts best... Think trying to go through the BCN is a good idea.
Posts.Title: healthy breast????

Posts.Content: flower stage 1, 2 and 3 is still early breast cancer.... the treatment is usually the same regardless of the stage except you may need chemo..... you will get out of this mess by having treatment. the way it works is cancer cells take years to go from a single cell to the size to show up on mammogram or be felt as a lump.... even a very small cancer will have been growing for years.... a few more weeks waiting will not be making any difference. the doctors very rarely make a mistake.... even if the breast cancer itself is bigger than initially though eg it could be a more extensive area that the two tumours are in.... normally  with multifocal disease its one segment of the breast that gets disease so unlikely to be all the way through the breast. ultrasound is very effective at pinpointing areas that have shown to be suspicious on mammo or where a lump is felt.... what it is good at is seeing if you have cancer in your nodes.... none of your nodes showed signs of cancer in them so even if you were unlucky to have a couple with cancer its very unlikely to have spread beyond them, without having obvious positive nodes. i hope that makes sense. remember no screening or diagnostic tool is 100% but they are not far off that....  the thing is the cancer has been picked up the biopsy has been taken and your going to be getting treatment to get rid of the invader. now something to also bear in mind is that women who have lots of nodes involved may never get spread of disease, and those who do have cancer that has spread dont just drop down they can live many years... i have a lot of friends with secondary cancer... one having spread to her bones 12 years ago. so yes you dont know and that is utter hell on earth the not knowing anything is worse than the knowing.... but hopefully you will get lots of answers soon. maybe you need to give your breast nurse a call on monday... but also post all your fears and concerns on here.   take care Love Lulu xxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Sue the blood test for the menopause is completely unreliable so I would take it with a punch of salt.... The only reliable method of telling if you have gone through the menopause is actually if you are over 50 and have no period for a year or for two years if under 50. Without the influence of hormonal medication otherwise it's just a stab in the dark.... So our docs idea about the blood test isn't particularly wise as its only a snapshot in time.... You would need a series of blood tests taken about 3 weeks apart to see if they all showed the same levels.
Posts.Title: healthy breast????

Posts.Content: Hi flower Multifocal means theres two or more tumours within the same area of the breast... Usually they are all the same and associated with each other... Often with dcis in-between. Grade 2 isn't the highest but not the lowest grade either.... Grades relate to aggressiveness abd how fast the cells are changing so from your results yours is somewhere in the middle although can sometimes change after surgery and they examine the whole tumour..... T1 and Stage 1 means that the cancer is confined to the breast, 2cm or smaller and there doesn't appear to be any node involvement.... Again this occasionally changes after the full path results as it can sometimes be bigger once removed than on imaging. ER 7/8 is strongly hormone receptive so is likely to respond very well to hormone treatment like tamoxifen or aramotase inhibitors which you would normally take for 5 years. In some places surgeons are happy to do WLE if you have two small tumours even if a little bit away from each other but some will only do an mx if you have more than one area. If you have three or more they will pretty much do an mx wherever you are in the country. good luck Lulu xx Just re-read that they told you it appeared to be only DCIS at first look sorry if I have scared you about it being invasive but it is still early.... If it's stage 1 or even stage 2 or 3 that is still classed as early breast cancer and treatable and curable. Lulu x
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: Hi Carole It really is scary at the outset when you don't know what's happening but without the biopsy they often don't know much more... They will want to know the type of cancer and the grade and how receptive it is to hormones. Normally if it's a low grade tumour you won't need chemo but if it's a high grade then it's much more likely... If its positive for her2 receptors chemos also more likely and if you have positive nodes then you normally get chemo... The one standard thingies everybody has surgery but sometimes it's done soon after diagnosis bit in other cases you have chemo first then surgery. Mastectomy is done if its a large tumour or lots of small tumours. Lumpectomy followed by radiotherapy is the normal treatment. But there are so many variables this is probably why they haven't said much to you. Good luck anyway Lulu xxxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: I would agree with Kate, if your GP was worried it was something else he would be checking that.... He will know what meds your on and what your past medical history is so i think you are worrying needlessly. The side effects from tamoxifen tend to flushes, and sometime gastric upset or aches... Not everybody will have side effects..... This doesnt mean its not working just means your lucky.... Viruses are common so see how you feel in a couple of days x
Posts.Title: 2 weeks on tamoxifen swollen throat glands is it a side affect ?

Posts.Content: Hi Flower I was originally diagnosed aged 37 just a year after mum had finished treatment for BC.... My kids were bigger than yours age 11 and 14 but it was still a really worry.... Even though mum was fine I was worried that me being younger would be worse and spent a lot of time reflecting on my life as at the first appointment you just don't know how serious it is.... I had a fine needle aspiration the day of my clinic appt and they were able to tell me it was def cancer just not the finer details until the full path results came back the next week. Id been told they were gonna throw the works at me because I was young but turned out to be a grade 1 BC so didn't need Chemo... Only needed a lumpectomy as the invasive component was small.... 13mm. did have to get a reexcision as didn't get clear margins due to high grade dcis so had another wee op and got a wee bit more shaved off.. The whole thing including dcis was 25mm but didn't need an mx even though small breast 34b... Often depends on your surgeons capabilities and confidence. It is really scary at the start of the journey but it does get a but easier along the way.... I have lost good friends to BC too along the way but doesn't mean that will happen to me too... Although have a gene mutation and had BC three times now so it does make you wonder a bit but it's all still confined locally so far. Treatment isn't fun but you get through it.... I'm a very optomistic person generally but think the antidepressants have def helped during my last two diagnoses. Take care Lulu x
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: hey Flower yeah im a registered nurse and midwife.... i work as screening and genetics breast care nurse and also as a family planning nurse but have given up midwifery now. i hope now your family know and have gotten over their initial shock they will be supportive to you. BC is now treated as a chronic disease but that doesnt make being diagnosed any easier... its still those words cancer and no matter how good your prognosis or cancer type... being told you have cancer is devastating. because its such a common disease it gets lots of media coverage (good and bad) but this means everybody is aware of it and it gets lots of money poured into research.... the problem with finding a cure is its not just one disease... when you add all the different subtypes there are around 200 types of breast cancer... many are curable and most people diagnosed with BC today will survive it so are inevitably are cured but he doctors just cant predict who will and who wont get progression of disease. the reason prognosis is found to be poorer is partly because i think women think its an old ladies disease so dont always worry too much when they get lumps and can put off getting it investigated, and when they do get it investigated GPs dont always act as per their protocols and may delay sending women for investigations... but also because younger women tend to get more aggressive cancers they are more likely to be a faster growing grade 3 than a slower growing grade 1 and are more likely not to respond to hormones which limits the types of treatments that can be given i was interested that you had no symptoms.... what did your gp refer you based on?   Lulu xxx
Posts.Title: Age 37 shock at breast clinic yesterday. totally dazed and reeling...

Posts.Content: I had E-CMF 2 1/2 years ago.... And actually preferred the epirubicin as although it made me feel worse than the cmf I also recovered quicker and felt almost normal for a week every cycle but with the cmf I didn't feel as bad but didnt feel as good either.... Some people prefer to feel a little bit naff all the way but I liked my good week on Epi........ I also had vein damage after my first epi and had similar feeling to cording I'd had after surgery 3 years earlier..... But didn't get a line put in as my unit do not do them unless they have major hassle getting a line in...... I think one of the worst things about the E-CMF is the fact it's an 8 cycle chemo where many are now 6 cycles so makes it a couple of months longer but the time does fly in pretty quick..... I felt a bit sick after the epi and had bad taste... Had quite a bit of energy on chemo day and would go shopping on he way back from treatment.... Had a curry the next night but couldn't eat curry on cmf as got sore mouth and ulcers but not on epi..... It's hard to remember the side effects now as they do fade with time.... Just remember feeling generally crap and tired...... Hope its going ok for you both.... lulu x
Posts.Title: E-CMF Side effects

Posts.Content: Sally my hair started to come out around day 14 (from my lady garden sorry if tmi) and from my head th next day and shave it off on day 17 and it was a relief to be rid of it as it was pretty sore before it fell out. Bit like forks being stabbed in my head.... It started growing back in on cmf though..... I was off on sick leave for 10 months after diagnosis.... Partly because I worked 50miles away and couldn't face the commute and partly cos I felt completely poop with chemo brain and no concentration..... I had the indigestion too and was given omeprazole from the chemo unit.... And also ad very watey gritty eyes it's cursed by dry eyes and was given hypromellose eye drops from the chmo unit... Both these problems persisted long after chemo ended..... I had pains in my face and head while getting the cyclophosphamide infusion the C of CMF..... it's fairly common to get a tickly nose but my experience was. Bit extreme but can happen also had a massive sneezing fit.... But this all only lasted for about 20 mins thn went back o normal..... Also on the hair issue.... Lost all my nose hairs and ended up with an alternating crusty or runny nose.... Eyelashes all fell out after I started cmf.... Didn't lose all my eyebrows and had to shave my legs throughout treatment!!! Lulu
Posts.Title: E-CMF Side effects

Posts.Content: Hi VJ I'm also treated in Edinburgh..... I had a wle but had to have a further revision for unclear margins in 2006. My tumour was smaller was only 1.5cm but there was lots of DCIS making it about 3cm.... I also had a wle in the other side in 2009 when I got another tumour it was also about 3cm including DCIS of which 2cm was invasive..... I have quite small breast B cup but they pretty good..... If you have larger breasts and the tumour is near the edge then they can often take a bigger tumour without making your breast look odd... If removing a rumour makes you uneven they can do a reduction on the ther side too.... Good luck with your op hope all goes well on fri.
Posts.Title: Change of plan WLE not Mx - Hope!

Posts.Content: Hi Hilary I agree with you some people are trying to live their lives rather than dwelling on fighting for them..... Where are you wanting the Botox? Is it a lip/facial thing or do you mean to your breast following treatment? If it's lipofill or fat transfer to your breast then you would normally need to wait at least 6-12 months after radiotherapy as the rads can make the tissue shrink more over the next 12 months or longer. If it's a facial thing then I think it's probably fine to have it unless your on treatment which it may interfere with but your doc should be able to advise you on that. Lulu x
Posts.Title: Is botox allowed nearly a month since radio finished?

Posts.Content: I just booked with travelinsuranceweb.com and was cheapest and best cover for my needs... Also heard mia online and insurepink are quite good but it depends on your own circumstances and any medical problems or you or family.
Posts.Title: Holiday insurance

Posts.Content: Hi Hilary I agree with you some people are trying to live their lives rather than dwelling on fighting for them..... Where are you wanting the Botox? Is it a lip/facial thing or do you mean to your breast following treatment? If it's lipofill or fat transfer to your breast then you would normally need to wait at least 6-12 months after radiotherapy as the rads can make the tissue shrink more over the next 12 months or longer. If it's a facial thing then I think it's probably fine to have it unless your on treatment which it may interfere with but your doc should be able to advise you on that. Lulu x
Posts.Title: Is botox allowed nearly a month since radio finished?

Posts.Content: Jamesay I had low bloods for 6 out of 8 chemos and needed them redone on the day and every time they were fine by chemo day... It's surprising how much they can come up overnight.... Even my last one was 0.15 the day before but 1.00 on the day so still got chemo and antibiotic cover.... Needed AB cover about three times cos neuts were still under 1.5 but were over 1...... Fingers crossed for you hunny xxxx
Posts.Title: chemo delayed a week ..so upset

Posts.Content: Hi Kaz I was diagnosed with breast cancer for the 3rd time last august and currently under going Chemo too. I know when I got it for the second time that was the worst experience of the three.... I think because every bodies biggest fear is getting cancer again and when it actually happens it's such a shock and so traumatic..... When I got it the 3rd time it wasn't such a horrific shock and just kinda felt here we go again. If your not happy with your reconstruction why not arrange to see your surgeon to let him check it out and see if there is anything else they can do to improve things.... Often reconstruction is not just one operation but a process of operations.... If your due radiotherapy they probably wouldn't want to do anything until around 6-12 months after that. Also many breast units have counsellors and psychologists and it might be helpful to discuss your fears with somebody neutral.... I found it very helpful to talk things over and also had a course if anti depressants which help me through those very very dark days. Take care Lulu x
Posts.Title: Breast cancer diagnosed for the second time

Posts.Content: Sasha are you not in the uk? All uk units should have a breast care nurse specialist.... Or at least a cancer nurse specialist even if she covers more cancers than just breast alone. Its tough going though this but you do kinda need that person to explain what the onc meant or find information from etc.... You can maybe use the helpline number to get some advice from the mac nurses xxxx irene hope you didnt get any elephants stuck in your teeth! Lol! Glad you are through your treatment and the no hair, no boobs, and extra Kgs can all be remedied in time xxxxx
Posts.Title: Getting there

Posts.Content: Hi sasha..... They can change the hormonal or herceptin status in a couple of ways.... One is that is could be on the borderline betweeen the two... For example with HER2 a score of 0 or 1 is neg and a score of 3 is positive but if its a two it requires further testing usually called a fish test.... I think that if its over 2 its generally positive and under 2 is usually negative... So 2.1 is positive and 1.9 is neg.... It could be that there is a tiny bit more or a tiny bit less of that protien wehn they test it again..... Also similar for hormones that it could be on the borderline.... Some oncs treat 3/8 as neg where as some treat it as positive... It is positive but a very low positive score... However may still benefit from hormonal treatment...... the other way it can change is because its a a sneaky wee bugger and can get used to the treatment... So if you are taking hormones it can built up resistance a bit like infections do to antibiotics..... So for years it could be kept under control by the treatment you have had and then after many attempts figures out that if it drops the hormones it might be able to grow a bit more. you can also get a new unrelated cancer so you can have two primary breast tumours one that might be hormone positive and one might be hormone negative.... This is what happened to me.... My first BC was grade 1 ER pos 7/8 and second was in the other breast three years later and was grade 3 Triple neg for ER, PR and HER2. So it hadnt changed they were two different cancers.... Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: Cancer changing its hormone status

Posts.Content: Was going to say it could be a seroma so hopefully you will know by now.... Also thoughh it perhaps could be scar tissue. Take care x
